plants.name: Crocus sativus
plants.description: A small, perennial flowering plant known for its vibrant purple flowers and the valuable saffron spice obtained from its stigmas. It blooms early in the spring.
plants.location: Mediterranean region, Southwest Asia, cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Saffron crocus flowers are harvested by hand to extract stigmas, making saffron the world's most expensive spice by weight.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A hardy perennial known for its white or pink-tinged flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring, often before other plants start to flower.
plants.bloomingSeason: December to March, sometimes into April
plants.location: Europe, especially mountainous regions like the Alps
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas rose typically blooms around Christmas but can bloom well into March, symbolizing hope in winter.

plants.name: Magnolia √ó soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid deciduous tree admired for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that open before the leaves, marking early spring.
plants.location: Native to China but widely cultivated in temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Magnolia flowers evolved before bees, so they are often pollinated by beetles, some of the oldest insect pollinators.

plants.name: Prunus persica
plants.description: The flowers of the peach tree are pink and bloom on bare or budding branches, heralding the arrival of spring and fruiting season.
plants.location: East Asia originally; widely cultivated in temperate regions globally
plants.funFact: In East Asian culture, peach blossoms are symbols of longevity, prosperity, and romance, especially around the Lunar New Year.
